content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS." is a condensed summary of the section title and findings. The Birth Defects Prevention Act of 1998, also known as the "Short Title," highlights the significant impact of birth defects on infant mortality. It emphasizes the lifelong challenges faced by thousands of infants born with serious birth defects annually, affecting infants of all racial and ethnic backgrounds. Certain populations, such as Hispanic-American and African-American infants, are at higher risk for specific birth defects. Prevention efforts for birth defects are hindered by lack of information and underdeveloped surveillance. Public awareness programs using folic acid and alcohol avoidance are crucial to prevent birth defects like spina bifida and Fetal Alcohol Syndrome. Programs regarding birth defects are being amended under Section 317C of the Public Health Service Act to address prevention efforts and public awareness programs for conditions like spina bifida and Fetal Alcohol Syndrome. The Secretary, through the CDC Director, will conduct programs to collect data on birth defects, operate research centers for prevention, and provide public education on prevention. Data will be collected by gender and racial/ethnic group. The Secretary will collect data on birth defects by gender and racial/ethnic group, including Hispanics, non-Hispanic whites, Blacks, Native Americans, Asian Americans, and Pacific Islanders. Data will be collected from various sources such as birth certificates, death certificates, and hospital records. States are encouraged to improve programs for data collection and analysis on birth defects. Additionally, a National Information Clearinghouse on Birth Defects will be established to disseminate information on prevention to health professionals and the public. Grants and contracts will be provided for these initiatives. The Secretary may provide grants and contracts to public and nonprofit entities for supplies and services to aid in carrying out the purposes of the award. Payments under the award will be reduced by the costs of detailing officers or employees to the recipient. The Secretary may provide grants and contracts to public and nonprofit entities for supplies and services to aid in carrying out the purposes of the award. Payments under the award will be reduced by the costs of detailing personnel and the fair market value of any supplies, equipment, or services provided by the Secretary. An application for the award must be submitted in the required form and manner. The Secretary shall submit a biennial report to the Committee on Commerce of the House of Representatives. The Secretary shall submit a report to the Committee on Commerce of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Labor and Human Resources of the Senate, containing information on birth defects, infant mortality, racial and ethnic groups, effectiveness of prevention approaches, activities conducted, and recommendations. The provisions of this section are subject to privacy laws under section 552a of title 5, United States Code. Federal laws on privacy apply to the data collected. $30,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1999, $40,000,000 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for fiscal years 2001 and 2002.
